dialogues.text: Mary stands at the front of the full elevator, smiling, a piece of paper gripped in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When I was a fledgling (that means novice) crossword constructor, I would find comfort in the words of the learned crossword sages. Above all, my hero is Manny Nosowsky, frequent New York Times contributor and all around cruciverbial master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks out of the elevator and heads through the offi Nobody seems to notice her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Manny says that a crossword puzzle's greatness can be determined by asking three simple questions. She marches in the direction of the Editor's office.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is it solvable? She almost collides with a mail cart but keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is it entertaining? She arrives at the Editor's office, plants her feet in th doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Does it s arkle? She looks down at the crossword puzzle in her hands, smil holds it out for Soloman. Soloman grabs the crossword and hands it right to the Assistant, who rushes it out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two OLD LADIES sit under the hair dryers, each doing the Atlanta Citizen crossword puzzle. They're stumped. The first Old Lady hollers over the noise of the dryer.

dialogues.speaker: I CAN'T GET ANY OF THESE
dialogues.text: The other Old Lady holds up her blank crossword, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TAXI DRIVER sits in the parked taxi doing the crosswo

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: This is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long haired GUY gets up from his seat, puts his coat on male EXECUTIVE sits down and spots the newspaper opened t the crossword puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even bother, man. I don't know what the deal is, but it looks like all the answers are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soloman holds up the crossword page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve? Mary sits and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every single answer is "Steve"? Who the hell is Steve anyway? No wait, I don't care, but I do care that you pissed off our readers. Mary's smile falls a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you knew better than to pull something like this. It's unprofessional, it's -- to him. He's too frustrated, the words aren't coming

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romantic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creativo? That's Italian for "creative".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary. We're letting you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. up her Kroger She looks like she's going to cry. She picks bag, fidgets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I could make it up to you by doing a fishing themed crossword. I know how you love the piscatology. Soloman shakes his head -- it's done. Mary hesitates then finally gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll just give you some time then. We'll talk next week.
He ignores that. She walks out, seemingly content, a bit denial. A PAYROLL CLERK sees the elevator doors close behind Mary

dialogues.speaker: PAYROLL CLERK
dialogues.text: She forgot her severance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you mean "Steverance"? They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks up to the front steps where Mr. Horowitz sits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: waiting for her. She sits down beside him. He holds up Atlanta Citizen crossword.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Interesting way to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: They like it? She points to the other newspaper in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finished with the Times? She goes to take the paper. He stops her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Neshama, the puzzle. How'd it go? She looks around. Nowhere to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think? She looks at him -- worry all over his face. She hesitate for a moment then sucks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you're thinking that they loved it, that they thought it was imaginative and bold and evocative... you would be right.
He's not sure how to take that.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: And Steve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works a lot, you know. Travels all the time. 'Tis possible he has not yet espied it. She picks up the crossword, admires it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when he does, I'm sure he'll say, "that Mary Horowitz... is a catch. Where oh where has she been all my empty life? From here onward my life will be divided into 'before I met Mary' and 'after I met Mary' with the second part being far superior. I am lonely no more. The missing letter in my puzzle has at last been found."

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: I don't want you getting your hopes up too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exec office. Steve relaxes on the sofa next to Angus while Hartman noses around the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to hit rush. We'll have to take the second flight. Exec. Producer DAN CORBITT walks in, heads straight for h desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're set. KDFW's on site now. Angus and Steve start to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on. They sit. Corbitt grabs the remote control, turns the TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody want to tell me about this? He fast forwards through footage of Hartman reporting fro greenhouse. Corbitt slows it to normal speed, mutes it. They watch as Hartman interviews an attractive female BOTANIST holding a test tube with a seedling in it. Hartm keeps pointing to the seedling - which happens to be righ front of the Botanist's generous breasts. The camera gets closer and closer - each time it pulls aw Hartman points to the seedling again to force the camera close - basically turning the piece into a giant boob-fes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at those... plants. Corbitt pauses it on the worst shot, looks at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't use this. Hartman fakes disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. Nice camera work, Stevie. Steve glares at Hartman. Corbitt points at the frozen sho on the TV screen, looks at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go back to the Weather Channel, try that again. Corbitt checks his watch, points them out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Don't embarrass me in Dallas. Hartman, Angus and Steve walk out. Steve nods to Hartman thanks asshole. In the hallway, Steve's cell phone rings. He answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?... Mom, let me call you back.
He listens, signals to Angus he needs a minute, then stop a reception area. He sorts through the newspapers, pulls the Atlanta Citizen, flips through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What page? He finds Mary's crossword. He looks at it closely, totall confused. It takes him more than a second to get it. He laughs -- then suddenly reality sets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary does a crossword while soaking in the bathtub. Witho missing an answer, she reaches over the side of the tub, grabs the telephone on the floor. She checks the dial ton hangs up quickly, continues with the puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four letter word for am I going to wait my whole life for Steve to call? She suddenly stops writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. She flails out of the tub like a salmon heading upstream, grabs a towel barely big enough to cover her. Without any effort to dry off, she runs out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Towel wrapped around her but barely covering, Mary reache the top of the stairs. Her wet feet sliding all over the place, she opts for the safety of a banister slide. She g up on it, slides a few inches before realizing what a bad idea it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow ow ouch. She gets off the banister, slops the rest of the way down stairs, jumps into the doorway of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news is Steve's life! It's not just what he does, it's who he is, imbedded deep down in his polymer of nucleotides. I should be out there by his side. That's what girlfriends do, isn't it? Let him concentrate on his work. I'll concentrate on the relationship. It won't be easy, I know, but neither is quantum physics or... the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle or... paper mache, but I've managed to do fine with those, haven't I? She looks at her parents. They sit at a table playing bri with MR. and MRS. HANCOCK.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Mary, you remember the Hancocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top of the evening. Mr. Hancock checks out Mary's bare legs as she stands in puddle of bath water. Mrs. Hancock lifts her husband's ch snaps him out of it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Loved this week's puzzle, dear. Whoever Steve is, he must be a very lucky young man. Mr. Horowitz gives Mrs. Hancock a look - "don't encourage her".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly! And all I have to do is go to him, be near him, and do my best to radiate... me. Mr. Horowitz doesn't like the sound of this.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: And where exactly will this radiation take place? Mary rushes to the TV, turns it on, flips it to CNN.
A shot of the Medieval Times castle in Dallas, TX. The banner on the screen reads "WORKPLACE KILLING".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever news happens, Dad. Wherever news happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASSENGERS board the bus destined for Dallas. Way too excited in her red boots, Mary is the last in line. She h her mother then jumps up onto the first step of the bus. Horowitz holds Mary's knapsack and Kroger bag, shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: This is nuts. Mary takes the bags from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abe, Catherine, I'm off. I don't know where I'm going - The Greyhound Bus DRIVER hollers from behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geographically yes, I know. Figuratively, philosophically, spiritually, much less so. My entire life is before me. The world is my ostrea edulis... That means the edible kind of oyster.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: That's beautiful, sweetie. You sure you won't take mine instead? She tries to switch her leather bag for Mary's Kroger bag Mary resists, points back and forth between the two bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, two handles, two handles, they both hold stuff, what's the difference? Mrs. Horowitz goes to explain, gives up.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: That Steve shows any disrespect, you're on the next bus back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disrespect. Do you mean unmannerly, tactless, vulgar? Because he's a straight man, Dad, and some things can't be helped. But if you mean inconsiderate to me, contemptuous toward me, insulting, irreverent, uncivil -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go already! She steps up one more step, yells out to her parents and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know when I'll be back but I do know this- The door shuts in her face.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREYHOUND BUS DAY
dialogues.text: Mary waves to her worried parents through the closed door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) I'm not coming back alone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MEDIEVAL TIMES
dialogues.text: Local and national NEWS CREWS are camped across the road the Medieval Times castle. Among them, Steve holds the CN camera on Hartman. A young audio tech JOSH hovers nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula, what started out as a routine rehearsal here at the Dallas Medieval Times turned deadly when an employee allegedly turned on his fellow performers. Twenty- four hours later, at least thirty employees are still being held hostage by the assailant, their lives hanging in the balance. He listens to his earpiece, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The castle you see behind me is one of eight medieval Times dinner theatre restaurants. Guests who cross the drawbridge enjoy a medieval style feast while watching the main attraction: knights engaging in a battle of strength and skill. The restaurant promises "fun, feasting and fighting" but it appears that this time, fun was in short supply. A few feet away, Angus frantically takes notes as he talk a MAINTENANCE WORKER, then slips a piece of paper to Hart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula, devastating news just in. We have one confirmed death - an Andalusian - a purebred Spanish horse. One of many that perform in the show, and the first innocent victim of a rogue knight's rage... He takes a moment to fake compose himself, barely getting words out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At times like this, I like to think there's a heaven just for horses. A rolling meadow, lush grasses, unlimited supply of... those things horses like to lick - or is that cows? Nevertheless, a beautiful, peaceful place. He turns and looks toward to the Medieval Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May you long roam in that heaven, noble horse - Angus hands him another note. Hartman scans it, instantly kills the fake anguish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not quite yet. We're the first to report, the horse is not dead, Paula. Not dead. The horse is alive and well after having merely fainted, as it was trained to do for the show. One happy, blessed miracle...
HARTMAN (cont'd) while a deranged madman continues to hold the lives of his coworkers in his depraved hands. And they're out. A pissed off Hartman pulls out his earpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, Angus. Get it a bit closer to right before you hand it to me. Josh moves in, removes Hartman's mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then we wouldn't have heard about horse heaven. Josh and Angus laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that kind of genius that won me the Southeast Idaho Christian Family Coalition's Journalist of the Year award, you ingrates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus is full. Most PASSENGERS sleep. Mary sits in the aisle seat of the first row, a BURLY MAN his 60's beside her. The light above their seats illumina the crossword puzzle he's working on. Mary looks over his shoulder, points to the blank spaces in his puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omaha... Einstein... cholera... grenade... Bach... oui... potbelly... Oreo. The man drops the crossword, glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. She looks away, starts biting her nails, then spots a sig the freeway, calls-out to the Driver and anybody else who will listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bessemer, Alabama! Named after Sir Henry Bessemer, a Brit. Guess what he did? Perfected the way steel is made, of course.

MARY (cont'd) I won't bore you with the whole story, just the best parts, like how it involves molten pig iron which does not, as one might think, have anything to do with pigs. It's actually a raw iron made from iron ore, plus limestone, plus coke - and by coke I mean the carbonaceous residue, not the cola, or the booger sugar. Mary looks around for a response -- nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what else is in Bessemer? The city, I mean? Hitler's typewriter. It's crazy, I know. That guy was such an asshole. The Driver's eyes glaze over. Please let this and.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls into the rundown rest stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Driver looks at the passengers. Most of them are stil sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just take five minutes here. He steps off the bus. Mary turns to the man next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you watch my stuff? He glares at her -- you have got to be kidding. Mary grab her backpack and Kroger bag and steps off the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks into the restaurant, heads toward the ladies r On her way, she spots a television behind the counter. A DINERS watch. Mary joins them. On the TV: "MEDIEVAL TIMES HOSTAGE CRISIS".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) Perhaps the greatest obstacle the hostage negotiators face is the suspect's refusal to communicate using modern day technology. In keeping with his role as a medieval knight, he's insisting on an eleventh century messenger to deliver all communication. The screen splits with a female news ANCHOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we talking about here, Hartman? Carrier pigeons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homing pigeons. A few of the Diners overhear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, homing pigeons. The Diners look at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrier pigeons, despite their name, are more or less useless when it comes to actually carrying anything. Homing pigeons are better for messenger work... The Diners lose interest. Mary catches the eye of a WANDE at the end of the counter. He's hanging on her every word

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who used them all the time? Genghis Khan. Loved the pigeons, scared to death of pooches though. The Wanderer just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, dogs, canines, de honden? Still nothing. She looks back at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have the negotiators located any homing pigeons? Where do you even get them in this day and age?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can buy them on the internet for twenty-five bucks a pop. Mary looks at the Diners, smiles, points to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boyfriend is probably holding that camera right now. The Diners ignore her and just eat their pie. Mary realiz the time, runs out of the rest stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary runs out into the parking lot. The bus is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap! Crap, crap, crap! She looks down the road -- no sign of the bus anywhere. S takes her paper bag out of her pocket, breathes into it. A TRUCK DRIVER passes her with coffee in hand, on his way his rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know when the next bus to Dallas goes through here?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Can't say I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed mine. She breathes double time into the paper bag. He takes pit on her.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: I'm headed that way. He points to his truck. Mary looks at the truck, looks at him, looks at the truck, thinks about it for a long time.
With no sign of an answer forthcoming, the Truck Driver k walking to his rig. When he's just about there, Mary yell out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever killed animals? He looks at her, surprised but amused.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Road kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set a garbage can full of kittens on fire or anything like that? Now he's disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humans?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Would I tell you if I did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touche, sir. Touche. Mary thinks some more.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Wait for the next bus if that suits you. He climbs into the truck. Mary runs to catch up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a .light? Matches, Zippo, blow torch, et al?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see your license? Why not. He pulls his license out of the visor, flashes i Mary steps up and grabs it, looks at it closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman James Durwood.
She reaches up and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Magdalene Horowitz.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER/NORM
dialogues.text: Good to meet you... I think. Still holding the license, she digs in her Kroger bag, pu out a large black magic marker. She pushes up her sleeve writes Norm's license number in huge print down her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norm, if you're going to rape and murder me, you'll have to cut me up into a million chunks and scatter me all over four states, otherwise this appendage - She holds her arm up, shows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will lead homicide detectives right to you. She smiles at him warmly, puts the marker back in her bag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you already told me you don't have a light to burn the flesh off. Norm can't believe this. Before he can say a word, Mary moves around to the passenger side, hops up into the truc She notices some snacks on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moon Pies! Want to go halfsies? At a loss, Norm motions for Mary to help herself. As she unwraps a Pie, he reluctantly starts up the truck.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MEDIEVAL TIMES
dialogues.text: Steve reloads his battery camera at the rental van. Angus looks over paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca wants you to come for dinner when we're back home. Her cousin from Florida -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. Never again. My mom set me up with this chick -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let you mother set you up? What the hell is wrong with you? There's a commotion in the distance. Every photographer o the grounds focuses on the castle. Reporters jump into position. Hartman touches up his make-up, roots through his bag. He yells out to Steve, Angus and Josh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one of you bastards hid my bronzing shimmer? The police surrounding the castle take aim. Dead silence as the Medieval Times drawbridge lowers. A KNIGHT walks out, arms raised as high as his squeaking armor will allow, which is not very high, but high enough get the point across -- Surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norm drives as Mary drones on while flipping through a tr repair manual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my other rule about crossword puzzles is this. No pencils. Doing a crossword with a pencil is like screaming with your lips duct taped together. It's weak.
MARY (cont'd) If you're going to do a crossword, you should do it fearlessly, with abandon, and with a pen. I prefer a medium tip, felt, blue -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet time might be good right about now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. She thinks about it, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean quiet as in softly hushed like this? Or do you mean quiet, as in silent? He nods. Mary squeezes her lips together, holds them. It lasts for about a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for not raping me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun comes up, Norm's truck drives into Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MEDIEVAL TIMES
dialogues.text: Norm's truck drives away, leaving Mary standing on the si of Interstate 35. She looks across the road to the Mediev Times -- it's completely deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight letter word for "screwed". Mary crosses to the Medieval Times parking lot, steps ove the police line blowing in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F-A-S-T-E-N-E-D. Fastened.
She looks around. There's nobody for miles.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's what's great about crosswords, and life. Every once in a while, you get a surprise. She heads back to the interstate, starts walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks past TV in the bus station tuned to Fox News. On every screen - images of an upset WOMAN dodging press get through the doors of Children's Hospital, Oklahoma Ci The screen caption: "The Fight for Baby Peggy".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary talks on a pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All roads lead to Oklahoma, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's parents share the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Last time I checked, freeway 20 still heads right back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary continues on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My road, dad. My road. You don't commit to a relationship and then give up because you'd rather be at home curled up in front of the fireplace with a thesaurus. This is what people are supposed to do - go out on a limb for love. My limb just happens to be in Oklahoma. It's only 850 miles away from home. No big deal.

MARY (cont'd) Just think of this like the time I went to Girl Scout camp, except for the part where I got kicked out. This time, no unsupervised butane experiment is going to ruin the adventure, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Horowitz hangs up the phone. Mr. Horowitz walks to t TV, turns it on, flips stations.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Oklahoma. Images of the Oklahoma hospital vigil are everywhere. Captions like "Breaking News: Baby Peggy" flash across th screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of local and national news vans line the streets surrounding the hospital. A long line of news crews, views of the hospital's admitt entrance behind them. At one end of the line, a male KOCO (Oklahoma) REPORTER talks to camera.

dialogues.speaker: KOCO REPORTER
dialogues.text: Eleven months ago, the child we've come to know as Baby Peggy was born with an extremely rare birth defect, a third leg. Shortly after the birth, her parents Misty and Bill Dunlevy separated. Now with joint custody, one parent wants the baby to keep the third leg, the other wants it gone... A few feet away, a female FOX NEWS REPORTER is on camera.

dialogues.speaker: FOX NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: After months of legal wrangling, a judge has ordered in favor of the mother. Amputation surgery is scheduled for Wednesday but the father, Bill Dunlevy, isn't about to give up. As his lawyers work to secure an injunction, the devoted father rallies public support for the extra limb.
At the end of the long line of news crews, Steve has the camera on Hartman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "God wouldn't have given my child the third leg if he didn't want her to keep it." But for now, the fate of that precious child's third leg is the hands of a judge... This is Hartman Hughes reporting, live from Oklahoma City. Steve signals they've cut, lowers his camera. Hartman cal out to Angus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if next time I say Baby Peggy is like the wishbone of her parents' dispute? Hartman acts out a wishbone pull. Steve's disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, go ahead and suggest that. Corbitt will love it. Steve turns and looks toward the edge of the fenced off hospital grounds. Dozens of PROTESTORS are camped out - a sorry assortment of oddballs standing at the fence, wavin their signs: "SPARE THE LEG", and "HONOR THE FATHER". Man of them carry drawings of a three legged baby wearing a h Steve braces himself and heads for the crowd. Half way across, he spots a loner walking from the parking lot. He 35, chubby, his shirt buttoned one button off so it hangs lower on the left. This is HOWARD. In one hand: a pro-leg sign. In his other hand: a carton of chocolate milk. Howard stops to lick up the chocolate milk spilling all o his arm. Steve catches up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I ask you a few questions on camera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel about what's going on here?
Steve shoulders his camera, focuses in on Howard's sign. It's an impressively detailed drawing of a judge yanking baby's third leg off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't made up my mind yet. Both parties have valid arguments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOSPITAL STAFF, PROTESTORS and the curious PUBLIC approac the hospital grounds. A taxi inches through the crowd. It barely stops when Mar leaps out like she's late for a Yanni concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary steps onto the hospital grounds and looks all around - NEWS CREWS circulate, PATIENTS and staff walk in and ou the hospital, protestors line the fence. Somewhere in the middle, she finds what she's hunting for -- Steve. Mary's face lights up and she starts running toward him - her mind, no doubt in slow motion, with clouds parting to light her way. Steve's attention is drawn away from the interview with Howard. He spots Mary running toward him, arms outstretch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please God, no. He looks for a place to hide but she's running ridiculous fast. It's too late. She's only a few feet away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve! She jumps into his arms but he's only got one arm free an isn't about to use it to catch her. She slides down his l to the ground but quickly picks herself up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here! Surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Astounded, flabbergasted, bushwacked - He pulls Mary off to the side, away from everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking to you. And noticing how the Oklahoma climate agrees with your complexion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me you didn't come all the way here just to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not... I went to Dallas looking for you first. And you know why? Steve grabs his head. This is not happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're inimitable and I'm intransigent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're not. I don't know what that means but trust me. We're so not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means you're awesome and I'm unstoppable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Listen, Mary, you seem like a nice girl, and the ten minutes we spent together were --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind blowing. At a complete loss, he just goes along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, but I'm working here. Working.
Mary points to the partially hidden side door of the hospital. A MAN with his face covered, in a nurse's unifo and dress shoes, sneaks out the door unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm just here to support you, show you I care, and also ask why you aren't following that guy pretending to be a nurse but obviously not wearing sterilizable, non-slip footwear. Steve looks toward the hospital, spots the Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was Baby Peggy's dad, that's how I'd avoid the press too. Steve takes off running. Mary yells out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right here in case you want to make out later on! Steve looks back, a bunch of people stare. Mary waves to then watches until he's out of sight. A SECURITY GUARD approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Miss, if you want to be here, you're going to have to stay behind the fence. Mary turns to see what he's pointing at - the growing cro of protestors off in the distance. They wave their signs around, cry, sing and sway together, their painful song barely audible from afar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near, far, wherever you are, we believe that the leg should stay on... Mary watches, paralyzed with awe, like seeing herself in mirror for the first time ever. At last, she has found her people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An overweight 30ish woman ELIZABETH (who shouldn't be wea those low rise pants and cropped tee) lights a bunch of candles in the grass behind the protestor fence. She reac the last candle in line just as Mary walks up to join the group. Elizabeth looks up at Mary, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I found them in an alley. Elizabeth looks at the boots again, impressed. She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you pro-leg or anti-leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the pro-leg group over here. We're supporting Baby Peggy's dad in his fight to save the baby's third leg. She points to the end of the fenced off area where only a protestors hold anti-leg signs:"NORMAL LIFE FOR BABY PEGG "3 LEGS ARE NOT BETTER THAN 2".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are the anti-leggers. They're all for the amputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just here because my boyfriend is working the story. He's with CNN, the world's news leader, the most trusted name in news, the place where more -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pro-leggers have better snacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm definitely pro-leg.
Elizabeth smiles, hands Mary a candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz watch TV and read at the same time. The TV is on mute --- CNN's Baby Peggy coverage. In the corner of the screen, "amputation countdown - 35 hours". Shots of the protestors' candlelight vigil appear the screen. Mrs. Horowitz spots Mary in the crowd, standing next to Elizabeth. She sings and waves her candle around, all the while straining to look for Steve.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: There she is! Abe, look! There she is right there. Mr. Horowitz glances up from his book.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: She's going to set her hair on fire with that candle.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Look, she's made friends. Mrs. Horowitz tries not to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the back doors of the rental van, Steve and Angus work laptops. Steve confides in Angus, trying not to wake up Hartman sleeping on the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's on me what, thirty seconds after meeting me, and the chick will not shut up the whole time. I had to fake a work call, gave her the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Steve) Wherever news goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm in the clear, then she does this crossword - she works for the Citizen - she does this crossword all about me, and as if that's not crazy enough, she shows up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over by the fence. Red boots. Can't miss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she hot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Angus. When a psychotic chick's swinging a machete at your throat, who cares if she's hot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been married to the same woman for seventeen years. I care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy, man. The chick is cra-zy. Hartman sits up, totally awake and never happier. He poin at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priceless! This is priceless! Steve cringes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hughes, don't. Don't even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short, 60ish PROTESTOR and his PROTESTOR WIFE talk to a Oklahoma Journal Record NEWSPAPER REPORTER at the fence.

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTOR WIFE
dialogues.text: All we're saying is, wait until Baby Peggy can talk and ask her what she wants to do with the spare.
Mary listens in while she dispenses a hot chocolate from another protestor's backpack thermos. She finishes pourin taps the guy on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Bruno. He walks away. Mary takes a sip of the hot chocolate, bur her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap. She grabs her tongue with her fingers. Hartman appears ri in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'lady. She's a bit stunned and star struck. He offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartman Hughes. Mary lets go of her tongue, uses her saliva covered hand shake his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary'. Mary, Mary, Mary. He takes his hand back, discretely wipes it on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve told me you were beautiful. He was going on and on and on and on about it. I had to come see for myself. Great boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank y- He puts an arm around her, pulls her away from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Mary, I've been working with Steve for about a year now. The guy is like a brother to me. A YOUNG PROTESTOR recognizes Hartman.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PROTESTOR
dialogues.text: Hartman Hughes'. Without missing a step, Hartman grabs a pen from his pock and autographs the guy's sign whether he wants it or not, then continues on with Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls follow us around everywhere we go. Who do you think they're after? Hartman reflects on it, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, of course me, but every once in a while some of them try to land Steve. It's true. Sure he'll go for a few skanks here and there but it's all just a sad attempt to hide his fear. All he wants is to love but he's afraid of opening up, afraid of putting himself out there, afraid of somebody like you, Mary - yes you - afraid of you breaking his heart. Can you blame him? She's a bit stunned and confused by all of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Promise me this. Promise you'll stick around long enough to help him get over that fear. He tells you to go away, don't. He says he thinks you're crazy? You're not. He's crazy, Mary. Crazy not to let down his walls and tell you how he really feels. Can I count on you to hang in there no matter what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I don't want to interfere in his work but I just need to be here for him and - He grabs her, hugs her in so her words are all muffled - yet she keeps talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good girl. The SECURITY GUARD walks past, gestures that they should behind the fence. Hartman holds up his press pass to get of the Guard, then lets go of Mary. He points her toward protestors, starts backing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell Steve to come find you when we wrap for the day. What side are you on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pro-leg. She shows him her button featuring a cartoon of a very ha three legged baby. Hartman laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to jump camps. No way they're going let that baby keep the third leg and live like a freak. Trust me. He waves and turns around, starts heading for the press c Mary calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd just be like the tree frogs. Hartman turns around. What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trematode parasite causes polymely (that means extra limbs) in tree frogs. It happens all the time. In some ponds there's like a quarter of the tree frogs with extra legs. Totally natural. Hartman looks at her like she's a nutcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angus is on his phone as Steve rushes to set up his equipment. Hartman arrives back at the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Josh rushes to get the mic on Hartman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parents of the kid got back together. Surgery's cancelled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No amputation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me you weren't talking to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell, Hughes. scans it Angus hands Hartman the press release. Hartman quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over? The kid keeps the leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For now. Hartman checks his teeth in a hand mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Til she gets it caught in a car door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: News spreads around the pro-leg protestors camp. They all start hollering with joy. The disappointed anti-leg protestors ditch their signs an storm off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Horowitz is asleep in front of the TV. He wakes up as the amputation countdown clock on the news stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news crews line the hospital entrance once again.

dialogues.speaker: KOCO REPORTER
dialogues.text: With mere hours to spare, the Dunlevys reconciled, agreeing to halt surgery until Baby Peggy is old enough to decide for herself. Further down the row of reporters:

dialogues.speaker: FOX NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: And while dozens of children fight for their lives behind these walls, Baby Peggy won't be one of them. With surgery cancelled, it's time for the Dunlevys to be a family once again. Past a few more news crews, at the end the line, Steve ha the camera on Hartman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And like the noble tree frog whose extra leg is nothing if not natural, so Baby Peggy begins the rest of her three legged life... This is Hartman Hughes reporting live from Oklahoma City. Hartman pulls out his ear piece. Angus, Josh and Steve al look at him, a bit surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tree frog? Where do you get this shit? Hartman taps the side of his head -- it's all up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little thing called astutitude, my friends. Steve and Angus look at each other -- is that even a word

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary celebrates with the other protestors. The Protestor his Protestor Wife cry tears of joy. Mary pulls a tissue of her bag, hands it over. The husband takes it, turns aw and wipes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go, George. Just a little nasolacrimal duct cleaning. Nothing to be ashamed of. Elizabeth runs up to Mary, hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? When you sing loud enough and when your signs are big enough, people listen! Mary spots some of the news vans pulling away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, go on. I'll watch your stuff. Mary drops her bags, runs toward the media camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh pulls the back doors of the van shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angus at the wheel, Hartman in the passenger seat. In the back, Steve nervously looks out the windows. Josh gets in next to him. Angus starts driving slowly across the grass behind other news vans. Steve finally relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the van drives, Mary runs to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve! STEVE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartman spots Mary in the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angus, hold up.
Steve sees what Hartman's looking at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, go. Fast. Hartman rolls down his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. Hartman sticks his head out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hughes, I swear I'll kill you. Hartman waves to Mary to catch up. Angus sees her in the mirror as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that her? She's hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angus, come on man, get me out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's really hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? Jesus, you guys - Angus hits the brakes. Steve hides behind the seat just a Mary catches up with the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi beautiful. Mary tries to get a look at Steve but can only see part o his back hunched over behind the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve? Are you okay? Is he okay? Angus leans over to her window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we've met. Angus. Mary shakes Angus' hand. He can't take his eyes off her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve's not feeling well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he'll be fine by the time we get to New Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your eyes are striking. Steve punches him through the seat. Mary's oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve really wants you to follow us. It would mean a lot to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve cringes, goes to speak up but stops himself and hidden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was going to go ask you himself but look at the poor bastard. So sick he can't even sit up straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it's a viral zoonotic disease? He should see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly what I told him, but the only person he wants touching his infected flesh is you. Mary looks at Steve, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But wait, what if - up. Hartman grabs her face, squishes her lips to shut her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey now, we need you to be strong for him. Leachinan trial, Santa Fe, can you remember that? Mary nods, unable to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll meet you there, God willing.
He lets go of her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take care of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like he's my own. She backs away from the window. Angus waves to her and starts driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing wrong with that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for those boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an asshole, Hughes. Hartman laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary watches the van drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a few protestors remain. Abandoned signs and garbage cover the grass. Elizabeth gets autographs from other protestors like it's the last day of high school. Mary runs up, grabs her bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth! I have to meet Steve at his next job, in New Mexico. He's sick, not as in rad, although he is that too, but more like unwell, infirm, perhaps barfy. Hopefully nothing serious but you never can be too sure and besides, healthy or not, he needs me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign my book before you go? Elizabeth hands her the ratty hand decorated book and a p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trip's not too long, right through all kinds of interesting sites like, for example, El Santuario de Chimayo: The Lourdes of America. Know what that is? A sacred sand pit near a burrito stand. What could be better than that? Mary looks away from Elizabeth, fidgets a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to go? Unless you're busy, I mean. You probably have something better to do. Elizabeth thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. Mary is stunned. She takes a minute to realize it's real, gets excited. From behind her:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I'll go too. Mary turns around and spots Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, have you met Howard? Mary shakes her head. Howard offers his hand. It's got dried chocolate milk all over it. She takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Howard. Howard, Mary. Mary, Howard's got a car, you know. He can drive us. Mary looks at him, thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of car do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plymouth Colt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty-nine. Mary quickly scans her memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Replace the recalled seat belts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Mary thinks about it, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's grab souvenirs! Elizabeth and Howard each pick up a Baby Peggy sign off t ground. Mary grabs as many as she can hold -- way, way to many. A bunch of them slide off but she perseveres.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Here's something you never see in crosswords, two letter words, and thank goodness for that. The word "go": not fun. The word "vamoose": super fun. You see? crosswords are just like life in that way - they're only boring if you have no sense of adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard starts the car. In the passenger seat, Elizabeth h a bunch of the protest signs crammed in at her feet. Mary gets settled in the back seat, spots a copy of Scientific American magazine, then finds an apple stuck behind the seat belt. She yanks the apple out, looks at i Howard looks at her in the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have that. I have more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Mary puts the apple in her Kroger bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard, if you get sleepy and want to trade off driving for a while, just wake me up and I'll take over.

MARY (cont'd) I'm a night owl, yes, but I'm also a day owl too, a burrowing owl, technically. They stay awake all day too. I'm pretty much alert 24/7, always have been. No caffeine. Just sugar and my natural tendency to, you know, never fall asleep. Mary leans back, closes her eyes, and she's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard's car merges onto the highway, westbound toward Ne Mexico and into the night. Mary sleep talks in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Persimmon. AKA, the mabolo, the date-plum, the velvet apple. Genus: Diospyros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A media extravaganza - local, national and this time, international news teams. A REPORTER for Inside Edition talks on camera.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE EDITION REPORTER
dialogues.text: This tragedy began eight months ago in what was once paradise - the Elysium Sanctuary outside of Taos, New Mexico. For years, celebrities considered the five star meditation resort the only true place for spiritual purification, and with good reason. Nestled in the heart of reclaimed Pueblo Indian lands, the Elysium Sanctuary promised one thing - enlightenment. A COURT TV REPORTER is on camera a few feet away.

dialogues.speaker: COURT TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: But the Elysium Sanctuary would never be the same after tragedy struck last winter. Twenty-six year old resort masseuse Juan Carlos Velasquez found stabbed to death in the meditation villa of beloved star of stage and screen, Cloris Leachman.
A bit further down the'line of reporters, an EXTRA! REPOR is on camera.

dialogues.speaker: EXTRA
dialogues.text: Publicists for the eighty year old Leachman insist her relationship with the deceased Velasquez was no different than with the dozens of other resort personnel attending to Ms. Leachman during her solitude retreat. At the end of the row, Hartman reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the octogenarian Leachman may not have been as innocent as her representatives claimed, at least according to the evidence found at the murder scene. Hartman reads from his notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whips, hot wax, bamboo skewers, a spanking bench, and perhaps most damaging, a henna tattoo across Ms. Leachman's chest that read "Mrs. Juan Carlos Velasquez".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, Mary and Howard step onto the curb and survey crowd. On one side, an odd assortment of fans with signs like "F CLORIS", "JAIL REAL CRIMINALS, NOT OLD LADIES" and "OSCAR WINNERS DON'T KILL", with photos of Cloris Leachman throu the years. On the other side of the crowd, a smaller group of MEXICA MOURNERS with signs "JUSTICE FOR JUAN", "GUILTY", and "LE THE BITCH FRY".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guilty or not? They all think about it. A greasy haired Shaman CLYDE ste up behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody deserves the benefit of the doubt. He looks at Mary, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody. As he joins the Leachman fans, Mary thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be has a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yay! I love Cloris Leachman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who doesn't?

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN MOURNERS
dialogues.text: jMuerte! iMuerte! iMuerte!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go find Steve. How do I look? Unwashed hair, bed head, and there's a chunk of a Twinkie caked onto Mary's ear. Elizabeth picks the Twinkie off, smooths down Mary's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back. Save me a sign! And if Cloris comes out, tell her I loved her in "My Little Pony: The Movie". Mary runs off as Howard and Elizabeth join the crowd of f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks among the news vans. At the entrance to a near tent, Hartman spots her, waves her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi gorgeous. What'd you do to your hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slept on it in the car. Where's Steve? Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never better. Come in and wait. He'll be back soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A briefing area is set up - folding chairs, table, podium bunch of male journalists sit around the table playing po Vince (CNN), DOUG (CNN), the COURT TV REPORTER, a BBC NEW PHOTOGRAPHER, a FRENCH PHOTOGRAPHER, A SPANISH JOURNALIST Angus. Hartman escorts Mary in. The guys perk up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all know Mary? Steve's girlfriend? Mary shakes hands around the table, greets them all in th native tongues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... Bonjour... Hola... Jolly afternoon... She gets to Angus. He kisses her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, sit. He shoves the BBC guy out of the way to make room for Mar next to him. Vince shuffles the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Mary holds her cards close to her.

dialogues.text: "There are few things that are so unpardonably neglected in our country as poker." Guess who said that one. She looks around the table. The guys, except Angus, are starting to lose their patience.

dialogues.text: Mark Twain. And you know what else-

dialogues.text: Thank God you're okay!

dialogues.text: He holds her back at arm's length, looks at her, goes speak then stops himself, pulls her outside the tent.

dialogues.text: Steve tries to stay calm talking to Mary.

dialogues.text: You have to stop stalking me.

dialogues.text: I'm not. It's more like picking travel destinations based on where you happen to be working.

dialogues.text: Stalking.

dialogues.text: Go home, Mary.

dialogues.text: And he said you'd say that too. It's just your fear talking. Steve just about loses it.

dialogues.text: He's not my friend, he's not your friend. He's just an asshole who thinks it's fun to string you along and make my life hell. He yells toward the tent.

dialogues.text: Hughes! Get out here!

dialogues.text: For the hundredth time, Steve, no, I am not interested in a threesome with you and your new girlfriend. Steve points to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her the truth. About all the crap you told her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Fine. Hartman goes to Mary, grabs her hand.

dialogues.text: Everything I said about Steve, about his feelings for you, his hopes, his dreams, his fears, his unexplainable odor, forget about it. Forget everything I said. None of it was true. dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Mary perks up. Steve yanks his hand off her shoulder like it's on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a love that defies words! Steve jumps him. Hartman fights back. Mary's horrified.

dialogues.text: Stop it, you guys! Stop! "Victory attained by violence is tantamount to a defeat, for it is momentary." You know who said that? Gandhi. And me. Just now. The fight continues. Mary half covers her eyes.

dialogues.text: Nice one.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: I'm going to go with Hughes on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, the guy wears makeup. The guys all start pulling out cash to place bets. Mary spots the cash changing hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! This isn't about money! It's about courage, love, honor and all things virtuous and pure. Steve, kick him in the leberknoedel! Hartman looks up at her, hurt. The distraction costs him. Steve knees him then follows with a jab to his face.

dialogues.text: Ohhhh! Hartman drops to his knees, tries to pull himself togethe

dialogues.text: Okay, alright. Hartman wipes his lip, looks up at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, millions of people believe what I tell them every night. Why shouldn't you? Steve dives at him. Hartman swings and gets him right in nose. One of their cell phones ring, then another, then a the guys' phones go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verdict's in. They all rush off to the court house, leaving a stunned M standing alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fought for me. Happiest moment of her life.

dialogues.text: The end to a difficult and often emotional trial, the verdict finally in, Cloris Leachman found not guilty of the murder of her twenty-six year old lover Juan Carlos Velasquez. Down the row of journalists, the BBC CREW.

dialogues.text: After a devastating eight months, Leachman at last vindicated despite overwhelming evidence against her. Six more cameras down, the French Reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyewitness testimony, fingerprints on every inch of the body, the murder weapon still warm in her Chanel handbag - And finally at the end of the line, Hartman - his hair a mess, his lip cut, his mood sour. A few feet away filming, Steve's nose bleeds down his chi and shirt.

Iraq, Somalia, Lebanon, Sri Lanka... and just about any place Cloris Leachman fans gather. Hartman wipes blood from his lip.

dialogues.text: This girl. She's been following me... She's not my girlfriend... He listens, clenches his teeth, hands the phone to Angus. Angus listens, Steve grabs his equipment, waits in dread. Angus hangs up the phone, hands it back to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm done?

dialogues.text: Consider yourself temporarily saved by the storm. It's worse than they thought. We've got to move. Steve grabs his equipment. They start walking.

dialogues.text: You already found what you're looking for. Mary's eyes soften and she's suddenly calm. A moment of peace. Suddenly, Mary spots Hartman, Steve and Angus rush past. breaks away from Clyde, rushes along the fence to catch u

dialogues.text: Angus and Hartman load up the truck as Steve turns back t Mary, seething.

dialogues.text: Considering you probably just cost me my job, maybe you don't want to talk to me right now.

dialogues.text: But I do! If you're in trouble because of me I can fix it, I can explain to your boss. He or she probably just doesn't understand our relationship.

dialogues.text: Mary talks on a pay phone. No pacing, no fidgeting. She means business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got him in trouble, Dad. I have to go find him and make it right. There's three places they could be headed. She pulls a note pad out of her pocket, looks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Enough is enough. You've got to get home, turn in your crossword for next week -

dialogues.text: I can't think of work at a time like this!

dialogues.text: You can't chase that boy any more. If he doesn't appreciate you it's ridiculous to -

dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz think about it for a second.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Twice. Seven times.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Give Steve my best.

dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.text: Sure you don't want to come along?

dialogues.text: And when I met Steve, I knew right away we had a lot in common. We're both in the media, we both love crosswords, we both love words. dialogues.text: If there's one thing I learned from crossword puzzles it's that you can't give up.

dialogues.text: I have to give it one more try. I have to fix the mess I made with his work, then maybe he and I -- For the first time, she doesn't seem so sure. Howard notices.

dialogues.text: Crap!

dialogues.text: There is nothing going on, man. Nada.
