dialogues.text: 15 DEAF KIDS bounce up a small hill, followed by three fe TEACHERS. When they finally reach the top, they all st op Ahead of them, down the hill, the Tri-Parish Fair - compl with carnival rides, pie contests, music, dancing, rodeo livestock shows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking while signing to the kids) Who's ready for some fun? The deaf kids start running down the hill, straight for t petting zoo.

Just when they're close enough to smell the goats, tgroun gives way from the back and the kids drop out of sight front of the Teachers - each kid taken tota off having heard the dropping behind them. A g lly i ant puf dust settles to reveal a gaping hole in the earth. The Teachers drop their picnic baskets and scream their h off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A messy living room, the TV on, nobody watching it. ON THE TV: "BREAKING NEWS - ABANDONED MINE DISASTER".

dialogues.speaker: CNN ANCHOR
dialogues.text: An abandoned mine shaft on the outskirts of Eunice, Louisiana. The children, apparently all hearing impaired, enjoying a trip' to the county fair, blissfully unaware of the danger that lay ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOX NEWS ANCHOR is on camera.

dialogues.speaker: FOX NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: No word yet on injuries. No word on when, or if, rescuers will be able to reach the special needs children. Well continue to bring you news as this tragic story unfolds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mary and Howard try to tip the car, Mary is distracted a rental van barrelling down the interstate, northbound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve drives, Hartman is next to him. Angus is in the bac with Doug and Josh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornadocane my ass. Where the hell were the cicadas? Retards in a mine shaft, now that's a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're deaf, asshole. They spot Mary and Howard up ahead in the ditch, next to car on its side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's your girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not stopping. Hartman grabs a piece of paper, writes fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't just leave them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Highway patrol's down here every hour. It's not like they'll rot in the ditch. As they get closer, Hartman rolls down his window, folds the piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting some fresh air. It helps my pores. Steve tries to grab the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hughes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Steven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not telling her where we're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't I?
Hartman leans out the window with the paper, waves it aro Steve reaches for it, one hand on the wheel. As he grabs Hartman, the truck starts swerving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, you two. You'll get us killed. Angus leans into the front seat, tries to steady the stee wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary spots the rental van approaching, swerving - Hartman waving a piece of paper out the window. As the van passes by, Hartman lets the paper go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartman rolls up the window, happy with himself. Steve sl him in the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asshole! Hartman laughs, rubs his arm in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary rushes to the ditch, picks up the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Eunice, Louisiana. Please..." She stops reading, looks a bit uneasy. Howard steps forwa grabs the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Please meet..." He looks at Mary, disgusted, continues reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-E-A-T. "Please meat me there. XO Steve".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? He needs me, if only to help with his spelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding. She rushes to the car, Howard joins her. They push the ca with everything they have, it tips back onto its wheels. jump in the car and start it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECURITY PERSONNEL guard the closed entrance and turn awa pissed off FAIR PATRONS. At the edge of the fair grounds, the ferris wheel casts a shadow over the rescue site. The whole area has been overtaken by RESCUERS and their equipment. POLICE guard t tape to keep ONLOOKERS back. Local MEDIA circulates. Hartman kneels at the back of the ambulance, holding the of one of the Teachers. Steve gets it on camera, all the while looking around, a bit paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what went through your mind when you realized they were gone? The Teacher just bawls. Hartman turns to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grief too strong for words. That's the best way to describe this tragic, tragic scene. One minute, a merry day at the fair. The next minute, helpless babes savagely sucked into the menacing abyss. The Teacher bawls even harder. Hartman gives her a "there there" then continues talking to camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's how hopeless the rescue looks at this moment. The earth surrounding hole is far too perilous for anybody to approach on foot. Moving heavy rescue equipment in too close could mean death for the rescuers as well. Its cold down there, wet, dark, probably a few snakes and rats moving around.

HARTMAN (cont'd) If the hearing impaired children even survived the fall, they're undoubtedly dealing with serious injuries, although some may have had their fall cushioned by their deaf brothers and sisters who dropped before them. Nevertheless, they've got to be in complete misery. Even if one them is telling the next "it'll be okay", it's not like he, or she, can hear a word of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coal dust covered kids sit in the dark, totally unhar A few of them play rock, paper, scissors. Others braid ea other's hair. An 8 year old boy signs to his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what the hell happened but I smell a lawsuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the taped off area, a crowd is forming. A school b pulls up and drops off a bunch more people. They place th stuffed animals, notes, flowers at the tape barrier. A bu of them start crying. Among them, some familiar faces fro the Oklahoma protestors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rescuers keep a safe distance from the perilous hole. A RESCUE SUPERVISOR oversees the effort, watches as a bucke attached to the old crane, barely big enough for one pers A FIREMAN gets in the bucket, doesn't fit. He gets out. A SKINNY FIREMAN is pushed forward. He gets in. The bucket is lowered into the ground. Hartman jumps in front of the scene. Steve follows with the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To some, a simple crane. To the trapped, innocent, special children -- the answer to their prayers. The cable lowering the bucket jerks and stops. The crowd gasps. Hartman stays on camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is it? The cable jerks and begins moving again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only time will tell. Through the crowd, Steve sees a WOMAN who looks like Mary from the back. fie freezes, then realizes it's not her. Total relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd, now even larger, waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard searches for a space to park. Every inch of the pl is packed with cars, trucks, buses. Mary prays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let those kids be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of cameras fixed on the opening to the hole. At the ambulances, the Teachers stand wrapped in blankets watching, crying. Steve steps a bit closer to the hole with his camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Buddy! Back it up. Steve backs up, refocuses on the hole as the cable rises. - it's one of the Kids Finally, a smiling little face appears being carried up by the Fireman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all okay! The rescuers cheer. The Teachers bawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd goes nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartman jumps in front of Steve's camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elation here in Louisiana but the danger, far from over as rescuers bring these children up one grubby little face at a time. Hartman looks off to the side, holds up a finger like he' trying not to cry. He signals Steve to cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remind me next time to mention Jesus. Still on the lookout for Mary, Steve's not even listening

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Howard run through the crowd. Mary spots George, the Protestor from Oklahoma and his Wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Lydia! What's going on? Lydia hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTOR WIFE / LYDIA
dialogues.text: They got eleven out. All fine, thank God. More coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve films as the rescued kids are wrapped in blankets, Teachers hysterically crying. The Fireman brings up another one. As he's raised to grou level he calls out to the Rescue Supervisor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last of them! As he hands the kid to safety, the cable jerks. He gets o of the basket just in time before the whole thing - baske and cable -- snaps off and drops into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary celebrates with the other onlookers as if she forgot she's there. She glances toward the rescue site and spots Steve on the side. She gets excited all over again, ducks under the ta and runs toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve films Hartman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A happy ending that's left parents across this country wondering - how can I keep my family safe from abandoned mines? Are there abandoned mines in my backyard? Is my child's school built on top of an abandoned mine? Steve spots Mary, running toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how, oh how, can these death traps be avoided? Mary drops right into the abandoned mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A monitor displays the current broadcast: "Breaking News: Abandoned Mine Accident"

dialogues.speaker: CNN ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Mary Horowitz. A painful high school photo of Mary appears on the screen Bad hair, bad make-up, ridiculously large smile, unfortun frilly chemise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUY watches the news on his laptop.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Mary Horowitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staff members huddle around the TV.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Mary Horowitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As all the other Journalists scramble, Hartman and Steve a bit stunned. Angus joins them, puts his phone on speake

dialogues.speaker: CORBITT, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Shame about your girlfriend in the pit, Steve, but we've got the inside advantage here so let's use it. Steve shakes his head, not impressed. Angus takes the phone off speaker, steps aside to talk to Corbitt. Steve's phone rings. He answers it, listens, cringes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Horowitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Horowitz cries into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: We're coming! Tell her to hang on! Mr. Horowitz runs down the stairs with luggage and Carol gerbil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve listens to the phone and glares at Hartman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your husband stay put, Mrs. Horowitz.
STEVE (cont'd) They'll have her out before you even make it to the airport... She'll be fine. I promise. He hangs up, looks at Hartman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She better be. Hartman looks away, guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete darkness. Mary's voice full of misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight letter word for... my life has come to this. There's a bit of shuffling around in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not destiny, that's only seven letters. Not fortuity - that sounds more like when good things happen to people like finding a quarter in the sofa or something. I mean the not so great stuff that's bound to befall some people more than others. Fate's nasty cousin, I mean. Suddenly Mary's face lights up with her mini keychain flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F-O-R-E-D-0-0-M. Foredoom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary shines the light on her knee. Her previous cut is no gaping wound, blood is all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State Troopers hold back the growing crowd. Howard looks toward the rescue site, worried. He tries to sneak under rope but a State Trooper points him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the hole, the Rescue Supervisor consults with the ot rescuers and a MINE SAFETY EXPERT.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: The new equipment is going to take a while. Let's try and find out what kind of shape our victim's in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we lower a phone down in there?

dialogues.speaker: MINE SAFETY EXPERT
dialogues.text: Not at those depths, this whole area is bad enough above ground. We'll never get a signal down there.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Let's keep it simple. Get me a flashlight, a piece of paper and a pencil. An unenthusiastic Hartman steps in front of the camera, t Rescuers in the shot behind him. Doug films. Hartman goes to speak but can't seem to summon his on air personality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind inc... Oh what's the point? Hartman walks away moping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve paces. Angus hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbitt wants you to go on air to talk about Mary. An interview with the boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not her boyfriend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close enough. Come on, we need this. Hartman steps up, listens in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox has already got their hands on everything but her panty size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox scooped us? Our Mary? The bastards. Steve glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RETIRED MINE SUPERVISOR comments as a graphic shows the cross section of the mine. As he talks, the graphic anima with a female figure in red boots tumbling into the mine bouncing off the walls all the way down -- and it plays o and over.

dialogues.speaker: RETIRED MINE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: That area was never reinforced up above, no need since the whole eastern tunnel was blocked off in the late Seventies. Of course that would also affect the air quality down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That has to be bad news for Mary Horowitz, wouldn't you say?

dialogues.speaker: RETIRED MINE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Definitely not looking good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Horowitz snaps the TV off, furious and worried. An upset Mrs. Horowitz cracks open the curtains, looks outside.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Who are these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slick, young JOURNALIST stands on the sidewalk in front the Horowitz house.

dialogues.speaker: SLICK JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Mary Horowitz, described by those who know her as smart, talkative, very much the girl next door, that is, if the girl next door has a genius level IQ. She's worked for eleven years as the crossword constructor for the Atlanta Citizen and lives right here with her parents. Mr. Horowitz opens the door an is swarmed by Reporters. T Slick Journalist gets right in there.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: No, Mary doesn't live with us. She just came over one day and won't leave, but she has her own place.

dialogues.speaker: SLICK JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Can you comment on the rumors that Mary's fall into the mine was a suicide attempt?

dialogues.speaker: MR. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous. Not our Mary. The word depression isn't in her vocabulary. Well, it's in her vocabulary, obviously, but no, nothing ever gets her down. Steady as a rock, that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary shines her light around on the walls of the mine. Bl soot everywhere, a mine track, abandoned equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not afraid. I am not fearful, pusillanimous, nor am I affrighted. Suddenly in the light - a face. Mary screams her head off The face doesn't budge - it's a LITTLE DEAF GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, they forgot one! You scared the crap out of me. The girl just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, can you hear me, I mean at all? Do you have sensorineural hearing loss or conductive? "Deaf people can do anything except hear." You know who said that? Doctor Jordan, first deaf President of Gallaudet U. Maybe you'll go there one day. That is, unless we perish down here. Mary smiles. The Little Deaf Girl just stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG RESCUER arrives with the flashlight, pencil and paper.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG RESCUER
dialogues.text: What should we say?

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Tell her help is on the way. We just need her to confirm she's conscious -- here, give me that. The Supervisor grabs the paper and pencil, scribbles the note, ties it to the flashlight. They look up to the thin nylon rope now in place of the snapped cable. The Rescue Supervisor signals for them to drop it. He attaches the flashlight/note, waves to the cr op. The crane swings over, lowers the rope into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary talks to the little Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then there's black lung disease, also a problem in coal mines. Chronic cough, breathlessness, cyanosis - that's where your skin turns purple -- There's a CLINK behind Mary. She turns her light onto the area, sees the flashlight and note hanging from the thin rope. Mary grabs the flashlight, turns it on, reads the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the hole, the crane reels in the rope, swings it away the hole. They see the note attached, flashlight gone.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: That's a good sign right there. The Young Rescuer grabs the note.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rescue team gathers around. The Young Rescuer the note, reads it slowly and loudly.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG RESCUER
dialogues.text: "I think you mean, am i conscious, not am I conscience."

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG RESCUER
dialogues.text: "Conscious means alert and awake. Conscience is your inner morality gauge, you know, the thing that stops you from doing bad things, e.g. killing, stealing, harming helpless animals, and whatnot."

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Can we leave her down there? He motions for the Rescuer to continue.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG RESCUER
dialogues.text: "To answer your question, yes I am conscious. My leg is bleeding but I'll probably live."

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG RESCUER
dialogues.text: "Yours truly, Mary Horowitz." The other rescuers start to disperse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "P.S. Did anybody lose a little deaf girl?"
The rescuers stop in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I found one. She's fine... Other than not being able to hear, I mean."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Alive!" splashes across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: FOX NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Breaking news from Louisiana, we've just received word that abandoned mine victim Mary Horowitz is alive.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. HOROWITZ HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz watch the "Alive!" news coverage. M Horowitz cries. Mr. Horowitz comforts her.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. FOX NEWS DESK
dialogues.text: The mine coverage continues.

dialogues.speaker: FOX NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Also in the mine, a hearing impaired child overlooked in the earlier rescue. Speculation now as to whether or not Mary Horowitz intentionally heaved herself into the mine to save the child after rescuers ignored her pleas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NANCY GRACE is locked and loaded.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY GRACE
dialogues.text: They missed a child? They missed a child? Can't these people count? Thank goodness for this woman, this Mary Horowitz - let's bring up that picture of her again. The picture of Mary appears on the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY GRACE
dialogues.text: We're looking at an American hero, folks. It it wasn't for Mary Horowitz, the child would have never been found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, Hartman, Doug and Josh breathe a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank Christ. Now if they can only get her out of there. Angus hangs up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbitt wants you on in five. Steve sees he has no choice. He nods. Hartman puts an arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be gentle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rescue Supervisor talks to the Mine Safety Expert.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: We've got the whole country watching now, can't afford any more mistakes. The crane from Shreveport is a wash. We're looking at as much as sixteen hours to bring the other one in.

dialogues.speaker: MINE SAFETY EXPERT
dialogues.text: Sixteen hours? If we've got carbon monoxide -

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: There's air coming in through the top.

dialogues.speaker: MINE SAFETY EXPERT
dialogues.text: Even at a concentration of 5ppm, they could suffocate... We do not have sixteen hours.
The Rescue supervisor looks toward the hole, of the sever and hopelessness of their situation showing on his face.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Let's at least get some food and water down there. The rope we've got on there now will handle a small load -- if that damn crane holds. He looks up at the old crane, worried.

dialogues.speaker: MINE SAFETY EXPERT
dialogues.text: Gas masks, oxygen supply, how long? The Rescue Supervisor points around the area - look where are.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: As fast as we can get them here.

dialogues.speaker: MINE SAFETY EXPERT
dialogues.text: Might not be soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - this The Retired Mine Supervisor is back with a new graphic time an image of adult and child sitting in the mine as g swirl around them and they eventually slump down onto the mine floor. It plays on a loop.

dialogues.speaker: RETIRED MINE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: They're pretty much done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As night falls, the crowd at the fence starts lighting an candles, passing them around. Among them, George, Lydia, now Carlos, the backpack dispensing hot cocoa guy from Oklahoma. They all look on, worried. Howard stands at the barrier looking more worried than anybody. Elizabeth pushes through the crowd to him. She's wearing red rubber boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard! She hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be okay. She will. Howard looks behind him at the ever growing crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this. For her. He manages a sad smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headline "Mary Watch" is broadcast on a mammoth scree over Times Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASSENGERS are glued to a news ticker that reads "MARY WA RESCUE UNCERTAIN".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening edition newspapers are loaded onto a truck. On th front page - "Mary Watch".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of LAUNDRY SORTERS are glued to the Mary Watch coverage on TV.

dialogues.speaker: FOX NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: The question on everybody's mind tonight is, who is Mary Horowitz? Atlanta affiliate WAGA looks into the mind of an everyday hero. WAGA Reporter CINDY emotes like her life depends on it.

dialogues.speaker: WAGA CINDY
dialogues.text: No one will argue that the city of Atlanta has always been a breeding ground for heroes. Jimmy Carter, Hank Aaron, Ryan Seacrest and now... Mary Horowitz. As the country wonders about what would drive this woman to such an extraordinary act, we went straight to those closest to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAGA Cindy interviews a sweet but NERVOUS OLD LADY.

dialogues.speaker: NERVOUS OLD LADY
dialogues.text: Mary Horowitz was one of my second grade students. Brilliant girl... Darling. Always a smart dresser as I remember. And she once brought me soup when I wasn't well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAGA Cindy reports.

dialogues.speaker: WAGA CINDY
dialogues.text: Mary Horowitz, a hero who's devoted her life to caring for the sick and elderly. Clearly a woman with a higher purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nervous WAL-MART MANAGER poses in the shoe department, holding a pair of red rubber boots. An excited FEMALE REPORTER points to the boots, talks on camera.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Exactly like the boots worn by Mary Horowitz when she slipped into the mine. Were the boots responsible for the accident? The manufacturer refuses to comment. For now, the deadly footwear remains on store shelves, leaving consumers to pay the ultimate price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three FOURTEEN YEAR OLD GIRLS shop online. They click on "Mary Boots" - a picture of red rubber boots comes up. A STATES". banner underneath reads "NOW BANNED IN 4

dialogues.speaker: FOURTEEN YEAR OLD GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh my God, we so have to have them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary talks to the Little Deaf Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhinolith, that's the real word. Rhino is nose, lithos means stone. Nose stone. You know what that is? Snot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAGA Cindy interviews a 30ish male SCIENTIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew Mary Horowitz in college. She caught me trying to cheat off her physics midterm, lectured me for an hour and when she finally stopped talking I asked her out. She said no, said it was because I was, get this - hebetudinous. Can you believe? He walks away, bitter, gets back to work on NASA rockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAGA Cindy interviews an attractive male RESEARCHER as he puts away books. He talks as though it still stings:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dated for a while but she ended it. Said she couldn't stand this - He points around 'to the library - you could hear a pin d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAGA Cindy continues her report.

dialogues.speaker: WAGA CINDY
dialogues.text: A heartbreaker, leaving behind a trail of devastation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary still talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Archimedes, there's another one. He was into math, philosophy, all kinds of stuff, then one day he was working out an equation in the sand and somebody stabbed him. Crappy, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus pulls up behind other parked and unloading buses. PEOPLE OF ALL AGES file off the buses, holding handmade " MARY" signs, stuffed animals, flowers, rosary beads, Klee They head toward the fence to join the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angus watches as Doug films Hartman interviewing Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, tell us about Mary, your fiance struggling for her life at the bottom of the abandoned mine as we speak. Steve glares at him. Hartman motions for him to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary... she's smart, incredibly smart. She talks a lot. Never boring, I'll tell you that much. He thinks about her, gets lost in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Horowitz doesn't pretend to be anything she's not. She's passionate, beautiful, real... and she definitely doesn't deserve to be where she is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spectators all gather, candles in hand, hands joined silent prayer. An ELDERLY COUPLE hands Howard and Elizabeth candles. How looks around at the rest of the crowd - strangers watchin waiting, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't even know her.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY LADY
dialogues.text: No, but they know what it's like to be alone, to need a helping hand. That's a good enough reason to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEIGHBORS hold a candlelight vigil on the lawn. The media catches every minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bar PATRONS are silent, glued to the "Mary Watch" coverag the overhead TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old crane lowers the small rope into the hole, smoke seeping out of the motor. The Rescue Supervisor watches, anxious and helpless. The other Rescuers just watch. Nothing to do but wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary still talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happenstance, I love that word too. And you know what else - Mary coughs. Before she has a chance to catch her breath, rope with a small bag attached quickly drops next to her, bag hitting the floor. Mary unties the bag and looks insi to find water and sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No dessert. Crappy. Did you know that the word dessert comes from an old French word that means "clear the table"? Sometimes I feel like dinner is just doing time so I can get to the point, and of course the point always involves sugar. Who needs - The Little Deaf Girl covers her ears, vocalizes as much a she's able.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE DEAF GIRL
dialogues.text: Shut up! I can't hear you but you talk a lot. Totally catches Mary off guard. She fully takes that in. Her demeanor completely shifts, a calm washes over her.,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. She sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. She notices the Little Girl's shoes are soaked. Mary move next to her, takes off her rubber boots and puts them on Little Girl. Mary puts an arm around her, holds her close - softly, her side, then speaks like she's a different person to herself, the Little Girl unable to read her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not good at... silence. "Mary doesn't do quiet", that's how my grandmother always said it. "What's that hush?" she'd holler at a party. "It's Mary about to talk", then she'd laugh and laugh and laugh. Everybody would... But I knew something they didn't - that if you keep talking, if you keep on talking, you don't hear people telling you that you're different. You don't hear people saying they don't like you. And if you're talking, you just might not hear it when some kid... calls you a freak. Mary's eyes start to well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to be normal, that's all. Steve said I was. She thinks about it, laughs a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to think newsmen can't entirely be trusted. She buttons up the Little Girl's sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is normal is -- not me. She seems surprised she said it out loud. There's relief it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends, the people I've met over the past week, they're not normal either. They're more interesting, more original, more real, more rare. She suddenly gets it, brightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where I fit. - and for She thinks about it, in silence. The sadness fades the first time, she's comfortably quiet. She smiles at the Little Deaf Girl. The Little Deaf Girl smiles back. And they sit -- Mary totally calm. Mary hears something in the distance - a gentle PLINK PLI PLINK she couldn't have heard while talking. She picks up the flashlight, moves toward the noise. In a corner of the mine, a water drip hits on some old rusted mining tools, including two rusty vice grips. The Little Girl coughs. Mary looks back at her, concerned

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Deaf Girl, it's time for us to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard, Elizabeth and Carlos watch from the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's taking so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz are glued to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Why aren't they doing anything? Mr. Horowitz grabs her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Laundry Sorters still glued to the Mary Watch coverag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet tension in the bar as the patrons all watch CNN.

dialogues.speaker: CNN ANCHOR
dialogues.text: A tense night in Eunice, Louisiana. Hartman what can you tell us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug films Hartman. In the shot behind him, smoke seeps o of the old crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've lowered food and water into the depths of this abandoned mine. The last task of this archaic crane that finally blew its motor. We've been told the new rescue equipment won't make it until daybreak. Until then, all we can do is wait, hope, and of course pray. There's a commotion at the rescue site. Doug zooms in.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE HOLE
dialogues.text: The rope hanging into the hole is moving. Rescuers get as close to the hole as possible.

dialogues.speaker: RESCUE SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Tell me she's not -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary cuts two pieces of excess rope off the bottom, attac each it to the hanging rope using the vice grips as makes climbing ascenders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After I got kicked out of Girl Scouts, while the other girls were learning how to sell cookies, I was at home reading the biography of Sir Edmund Hillary. Mary motions for the Little Deaf Girl to jump on piggybac She jumps up onto Mary's back, still in the red rubber bo Mary starts jugging up the rope, the vice grips and rope pieces acting like ladder steps. They start rising up slowly. Not an easy task. Mary struggles every step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot of the moving rope up above the hole is broadcast. People on the street stop and watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guys at the bar stand up to watch to the shot of the moving rope on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Horowitz on the edge of their seats in front the Mary Watch TV coverage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Little Deaf Girl helps Mary move one of the vice grip the rope.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If life is like a crossword puzzle then its worth, its greatness, its raison d'efre should be judged in the same way.
Mary grasps the cable with everything she has, pulls up another step.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is it solvable? One of the red boots drops down into the mine shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every eye is on the moving rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks up as the lights above get closer and closer.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is it entertaining?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Rescuers, Firemen, Troopers, Media and Public look Mary at last appears above ground, the little Girl in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Does it sparkle? The crowd goes nuts. Cameras flash. Rescuers rush to help them onto the ground. An Ambulance Attendant grabs the little Girl, wraps her i blanket. Mary's eyes flutter in the blinding lights of th cameras pointed at her. She scans the entire crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And does it fit? Her eyes fix on a spot in the crowd. She starts running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Horowitz hands her husband the box of Kleenex as the wail and watch Mary on TV, safely above ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The customers eat pie while they're glued to images of Ma and the little Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for her. Good for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff breathe a sigh of relief when they see Mary ali on TV. Jim Soloman stares at the images, happy, acquiesce

dialogues.speaker: JIM SOLOMAN
dialogues.text: We're going to have to give her her job back. He shakes his head, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody in the bar celebrates. The BARTENDER rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Career Day teacher watches Mary on TV, wipes her eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Laundry Sorters celebrate, then realize their laundry all pink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Large Kid from the Career Day class walks into the li room where his DAD has Mary Watch on TV. The Kid holds up crossword, half done, and he's not happy about it.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE KID
dialogues.text: Did you start this and not bother finishing it? Do you know how much work goes into making these things? Honestly, Dad. The Kid grabs a pencil to finish the puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Takihashi watches Mary on TV, wipes his tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary adjusts her eyes to the flashing lights, looks aroun An Ambulance Attendant tries to attend to her leg. She wa him off. In bare feet, blood running down her leg, limpin she starts running away from the site toward the media. Steve's watches, genuinely happy to see her. Hartman nudg Doug to get the camera on Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First interview is ours. Here comes our girl. Steve, you ready? Grab her arid kiss her then let me start with the questions. Doug focuses in on Steve. Hartman holds the crowd back so Mary can get to him. Mary runs toward them -- and keeps on running, right past Steve's open arms. She heads for her friends at the fence - Howard, Elizabet Carlos, George, Lydia, all of the other Protestors. She s dives right into them. They catch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. Cameras go off all around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Greyhound bus travels.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My brain is full of all kinds of information, some of it useful, some of it not.

MARY (V.0.) (cont'd) I've recently discovered, hiding in the back of my mind, somewhere between astrophysics and a catalog of candy bars of the Seventies, a previously hidden bit of knowledge more important than everything else. It is this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits right at the front talking to the female BUS DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In solving the puzzle of life there's one thing you must do. She points to the side of the road. The bus pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find somebody just as normal as you. Mary stands up, gets off the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: if not a whole bunch. Howard, Elizabeth, George, Lydia, Carlos, Clyde, a few ol Ladies, a bunch of other Protestors file off the bus. Mar keeps talking to the bus driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't be a slave to your loins. Trust me on that one. Mary taps the side of her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to let this be the boss of you. Cornprende ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge gated property. Mary opens the gate and walks up a tree covered path, Howard right behind her, all the other Protestors following. For once, Mary isn't doing all the talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bus driver looked like Francis Galton. Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my favorite behavioral geneticist in the world. They continue on through an open yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In retrospect, and I say this with some hesitation because I don't like to have actual regrets so I'll just say I'm beginning to perpend -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to perpend whether or not eating three bags of caramel corn for lunch was the smartest thing to do. Honestly I'm this close to spewing... Mary reaches the end of the path and stops, waits for everybody else to catch up. They're in complete awe of th monstrous Georgian estate before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandma left it to me. My parents won't stay here. And for me it was always too... quiet. She looks at her new friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore. They head toward the house.
